Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Modernization, Health, and Development in the Global Cold War

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This study will look at the difficulties that arise in defining appropriate medical technologies for four different types of organizations: non-profit foundations, multilateral United Nations-based organizations, bilateral aid organizations such as the United States Agency for International Development, and government contractors. This project will examine how recipients in developing countries have historically actively contested and negotiated the definition of appropriate technology. It will explore their role as designers of some of the technologies and the policies advocating for their adoption. This project will consider how technology transfer in foreign aid often affects women differently than men, specifically when looking at small-scale everyday health technologies. It will be of interest to development workers, citizens and policymakers because it could contribute to ensuring that development technologies are appropriate.

From its inception, the study of development and modernization has been bound up with questions of technology. Development critics often point to the over-use of certain technologies or the unavailability of others. Yet underlying these claims is the assumption that there must be a more appropriate level of technology that would lead to better economic and social development. This study will explore what makes a given technology appropriate. It will use oral history interviews, archival materials, and participant observation at the sites of current-day health technology projects in South Africa and Zimbabwe. Through this work, this study will consider how historical precedents have and have not carried through development practice in the modern day and will inform development professionals and policymakers of the specific ways in which the use of health technologies in foreign aid work have impacted the communities they intend to serve.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Heidi Morefield completed dissertation research for her project, now titled “Developing to Scale: Appropriate Technology and the Making of Global Health,” with support from an NSF Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. As a historian of medicine, Morefield was interested in how small-scale point-of-use technologies were being used in global health and development from the immediate post-war period through to the present day, particularly in American foreign aid. During the funding period, Morefield traveled to global health “innovation labs” in Seattle and South Africa to conduct oral history interviews and engage in participant observation. En route to South Africa, she was also able to visit an important archive in London that contained some papers and publications of the Intermediate Technology Development Group. 

 

Morefield accomplished her research goals, completing over 20 oral history interviews in both South Africa and Seattle with stakeholders that ranged from Executive Directors of large government contractors and philanthropic organizations, to mid-level project managers, to intended beneficiaries in the field. Through her fieldwork at these different sites and alongside these different constituencies, Morefield gained a well-rounded understanding of how technologies are designed for, selected, and used in the developing world through foreign aid, as well as how they are frequently adapted by indigenous stakeholders, and particularly women. This research forms the basis for her argument that the concept of “appropriate technology” and the movement in the 1970s and 1980s that advocated for its use in health and development programs formed the backbone of global health as we know it today. The focus landed on tools as the means to change the world, to the detriment of broad-based approaches aimed at prevention through primary health care.

 

Morefield also traveled to Sydney, Australia during the grant period to present her research findings at a special workshop on “STS in/and Africa” ahead of the 4S (Society for the Social Studies of Science) Annual Meeting. This workshop, which included many scholars from African institutions, was a very productive interface between Science and Technology scholars who study Africa from North American and European institutions and those for whom living there is a daily reality. 

 

Morefield’s dissertation, to be completed in 2019, shows not only how the economics of development and idealized visions of rural life in the developing world contributed to techno-centrism in global health today, but also grapples with broader questions of why health technologies deemed appropriate for one group may not be considered appropriate for another. The choice of which technology to use is inherently political and has historically been informed by assumptions of difference between communities.
